title: If Credit Karma says my credit score is 632 , about what might I expect it to change to, upon filing Ch. 7 -- and how quickly?
question: I know it's hard to say for certain -- but it could make a difference with landlords, and I might delay the BK until after renting, or do it before renting...
answers: We find that bankruptcy puts you in the mid to upper 600's. If you need to rent than do it before you file. Get into the place have your lease agreement signed so they cannot deny you then file.

You do understand that Credit Karma is nothing more than fortunetelling, don't you? Lenders only use the scores from FICO and the way FICO calculates scores is a secret proprietary method. Further, landlords seldom rely on the traditional consume credit scores but use a credit history based on reviews of your public records (for evictions) and utility payment history. Stop chasing after the bogus and focus on what is really important! Hope this perspective helps!

A score of 632 will generally improve within a year of a BK as long as no more negatives hit your credit. Enlightened landlords recognize that if you have discharged all your other debt, it's obviously going to be easier to make those rent payments going forward. Some "corporate" landlords who are governed more by bureaucracy than common sense may be less enlightened.

Your credit score is based on many factors. In my experience, by the time a person is ready to file Chapter 7, they are behind in their debts and their credit score has already taken a hit. In some cases, I have actually seen a credit score increase after a petition has been filed. Having said that, your credit score will usually dip downward. Prompt payments post bankruptcy on secured debts will go a long way in increasing your score. As far as your credit score affecting your ability to rent, that is an unanswerable question because different landlords use different ways to evaluate tenants. Large, corporate owned operations screen tenants differently than owners of a small duplex or fourplex for example. Some LL may even consider you a better prospect if you have shed most or all of your debt.
